statement.p: The following shows graphs of three functions, A (in black), B (in blue), and C (in green). If these are the graphs of three functions f, f', and f'', identify which is which.

p.em: (Click on the graph to get a larger version.)

statement.p: (For each enter A, B or C).

solution.p: SOLUTION

To determine which graphed function is the the derivative of another, we use the fact that the derivative is zero where the original function has a maximum or minimum. We note that C has zeros where B has a maximum or minimum, so it could be the derivative, so we can have C = B'. In addition, B has zeros where A has a maximum or minimum, so that it is possible that B = A'.
To confirm this, we compare intervals where B is increasing and decreasing and verify that these are where C is positive and negative, respectively, and similarly compare A and B.
This gives us that f = A, f' = B, and f'' = C.

statement.p: For some positive constant C, a patient's temperature change, T, due to a dose, D, of a drug is given by T = \left(\frac{C}{2} - \frac{D}{3}\right)D^2.
What dosage maximizes the temperature change?
The sensitivity of the body to the drug is defined as dT/dD. What dosage maximizes sensitivity?

solution.p: SOLUTION
We have T(D) = \left(\frac{C}{2} - \frac{D}{3}\right)D^2 = \frac{CD^2}{2}-\frac{D^3}{3}, and so \frac{dT}{dD} = CD-D^2 = D(C-D).
Since, by this formula, dT/dD is zero when D=0 or D=C, negative when D>C, and positive when D\lt C, we have (by the first derivative test) that the temperature change is maximized when D=C.

The sensitivity is dT/dD = CD-D^2; its derivative is d^2T/dD^2 = C-2D, which is zero if D= C/2, negative if D> C/2, and positive if D\lt C/2. Thus by the first derivative test the sensitivity is maximized at D=C/2.

statement.p: B. Where are the global maxima and minima of g on [-2,2]?
minimum at x =
maximum at x =
C. If g(-2) = 9, what are possible values for g(0)?
g(0) is in

p.em: (Enter your answer as an interval, or union of intervals, giving the possible values. Thus if you know -1 \lt g(0) \le 3, enter (-1,3]. Enter infinity for \infty, the interval [0,0] to indicate a single point).

statement.p: How is the value of g(2) related to the value of g(0)?

p.em: (Enter the appropriate mathematical equality or inequality, =, \lt , >, etc.)

solution.p: SOLUTION

Because the graph of g'(x) is positive for all -2 \lt x \lt 2, we know that the graph of g(x) must always be increasing there. The derivative appears to be zero at x = \pm 2, so the graph of g(x) must start out flat at x = -2, and then increases more and more rapidly as it approaches x = 1. After x = 1 the it increases less rapidly, finally flattening out entirely as we get to x = 2.
A. The graph has an inflection point at x = 1, where the slope changes from positive and increasing to positive and decreasing.
B. The function has a global maximum at x=2 and a global minimum at x=-2.

C. Since the function is increasing over the interval -2 \lt x \lt 2, we know that g(0) must be greater than g(-2), and so must be in the interval (9,\infty). (We note that it appears that the magnitude of the derivative g' is also less than one for the entire domain that we are considering, so we can actually give a smaller interval for the possible values of g; any interval between (9,\infty) and (9,11) is reasonable.)
D. Again, since the function is increasing over the interval -2 \lt x \lt 2, we know that g(-2) = 9 \lt g(0) \lt g(2).

statement.p: An open box is to be made out of a 8-inch by 16-inch piece of cardboard by cutting out squares of equal size from the four corners and bending up the sides. Find the dimensions of the resulting box that has the largest volume.
Dimensions of the bottom of the box: x
Height of the box:

A rectangular storage container with an open top is to have a volume of 20 cubic meters. The length of its base is twice the width. Material for the base costs 15 dollars per square meter. Material for the sides costs 4 dollars per square meter. Find the cost of materials for the cheapest such container.
Total cost = (Round to the nearest penny and include monetary units. For example, if your answer is 1.095, enter $1.10 including the dollar sign and second decimal place.)

solution.p: SOLUTION
Let w and h denote the width of the base and the height of the container, respectively.

Since the length of the base is twice the width, the volume of the container is V= (2w)(w)h =2 w^2 h = 20 so h = \frac{20}{ 2 w^2} The sides have total area 2(2w)h+ 2wh = 6wh, while the base has area w(2w) = 2 w^2, so the cost is 4 \cdot (6wh ) + 15\cdot (2 w^2) Substuting the expression for h gives C(w) = 4 \cdot 6 w\cdot \frac{20}{ 2 w^2} + 15\cdot( 2 w^2 ) = \frac{240}{w} + 30 w^2 \quad w >0 C'(w) = -\frac{240}{w^2} + 60 w = \frac{-240+ 60 w^3}{w^2} \displaystyle w = \left(4\right)^{1/3} is the critical number. There is an absolute minimum at this critical number since C'(w) \lt 0 for 0 \lt w \lt \left(4\right)^{1/3} and C'(w) >0 for w > \left(4\right)^{1/3}.
The total minimum cost is C\left(\left(4\right)^{1/3} \right) \approx \$226.79

Gravel is being dumped from a conveyor belt at a rate of 50 cubic feet per minute. It forms a pile in the shape of a right circular cone whose base diameter and height are always the same. How fast is the height of the pile increasing when the pile is 19 feet high? Recall that the volume of a right circular cone with height h and radius of the base r is given by V= \frac{1}{3}\pi r^2h.
When the pile is 19 feet high, its height is increasing at feet per minute.

solution.p: We are given that the diameter and height are always the same, so 2r = h,or r = \frac12 h. Hence, the volume of the pile is \textstyle V = \frac13 \pi r^2 h = \frac13 \pi \bigl( \frac12 h \bigr)^2 h = \frac1{12} \pi h^3. Differentiating with respect to time (t) gives \frac{dV}{dt} = {\textstyle \frac{1}{12} \pi \, 3 h^2} \, \frac{dh}{dt} = {\textstyle \frac14 \pi h^2} \, \frac{dh}{dt}, and so \frac{dh}{dt} = \frac{4}{\pi h^2} \frac{dV}{dt}. If \frac{dV}{dt} = 50 and h = 19, then \frac{dh}{dt} = \frac{4 \cdot 50}{19 ^2 \pi} = \frac{200}{361\pi }. Hence, when the pile is 19 feet high its height is increasing at a rate of \frac{200}{361\pi } feet per minute.

statement.p: A street light is at the top of a 10 foot tall pole. A 6 foot tall woman walks away from the pole with a speed of 5 ft/sec along a straight path. How fast is the tip of her shadow moving when she is 35 feet from the base of the pole?
The tip of the shadow is moving at ft/sec.

Water is leaking out of an inverted conical tank at a rate of 7600.0 \textrm{cm}^3/\textrm{min} at the same time that water is being pumped into the tank at a constant rate. The tank has height 14.0 \ \textrm{m} and the the diameter at the top is 5.5 \ \textrm{m}. If the water level is rising at a rate of 22.0 \ \textrm{cm}/\textrm{min} when the height of the water is 4.0 \ \textrm{m}, find the rate at which water is being pumped into the tank in cubic centimeters per minute.
Answer: \textrm{cm}^3/\textrm{min}

static.hint: R be the unknown rate at which water is being pumped in. Then you know that if V is volume of water, \frac{dV}{dt}=R-7600.0. Use geometry (similar triangles) to find the relationship between the height of the water and the volume of the water at any given time. Recall that the volume of a cone with base radius r and height h is given by \frac{1}{3} \pi r^2 h

solution.p: The volume V of a cone of diameter d and height h is V=\frac{\pi d^2 h }{12}. We might as well do this problem a little more generally than stated. (It actually makes things clearer to use variables throughout and substitute specific values only at the end.) So suppose the diameter of our tank is D and its height is H. Suppose the depth of the water is h and the radius of the surface is r. Then, by similar triangles, \frac{r}{h} = \frac{R}{H}, or r= \frac{Rh}{H}. Substituting in the volume formula gives V= \frac{\pi D^2h^3}{12H^2}. Differentiating gives: V'= \frac{3\pi D^2h^2h'}{12H^2} = \frac{\pi D^2h^2h'}{4H^2} This rate of change in volume would be the rate T at which water is being pumped into the tank if there was no leak. However, if L is the leak rate then T = L+\frac{\pi D^2h^2h'}{4H^2}.
Note that since we have to have consistent units of length, and the answer is in cubic centimeters per minute, the lengths given in meters have to be converted to centimeters.
Thus, substituting L = 7600,\quad D = 550,\quad H = 1400, \quad h = 400,\quad h' = 22 we obtain T = 7600 + \frac{\pi*550^2*400^2*22}{4*1400^2} \approx 434280 \hbox{cm}^3/\hbox{min}.

solution.p: SOLUTION

To find a lower estimate for the distance the car has traveled, we use the lowest velocity for each of the intervals 0\le t\le 2, 2\le t\le 4, and 4\le t\le 6 to calculate an estimated distance traveled in each interval. This gives \mbox{dist} = (44)(2) + (16)(2) + (0)(2) = 120. Similarly, for the upper estimate, we take the maximum velocity for each interval, to get \mbox{dist} = (86)(2) + (44)(2) + (16)(2) = 292.

Graphically, each of the terms in these sums is the area of a rectangle, as shown outlined in blue in the figures below. The lower- and upper estimates are the sum of the areas of these rectangles. (Note that the height of the last rectangle for the lower estimate is zero, so it does not contribute to the sum.)

statement.p: Two cars start at the same time and travel in the same direction along a straight road. The figure below gives the velocity, v (in km/hr), of each car as a function of time (in hr).

Which car attains the larger maximum velocity?
A
B

Which stops first?
A
B

Which travels farther?
A
B

solution.p: SOLUTION
Car B has a velocity that attains the largest maximum value.
The graph of the velocity of car B returns to zero first, so that car stops first.
The area under the velocity curve for A is largest, so that car travels the farthest.

statement.p: Suppose that an accelerating car goes from 0 mph to 65.5 mph in five seconds. Its velocity is given in the following table, converted from miles per hour to feet per second, so that all time measurements are in seconds. (Note: 1 mph is 22/15 feet per sec = 22/15 ft/s.) Find the average acceleration of the car over each of the first two seconds.
average acceleration over the first second = (include units)
average aceleration over the second second = (include units)

solution.p: SOLUTION

To measure the average acceleration over an interval, we calculate the average rate of change of velocity over the interval. The units of acceleration are ft/s per second, or ft/s/s, written ft/s{}^2. \mbox{average acceleration for } 0\le t\le 1 = \frac{\mbox{Change in velocity}}{\mbox{Change in time}}, so, reading the velocities from the table, we have \frac{v(1) - v(0)}{1} = 32.73 - 0.00 = 32.73 \mbox{ft/s}{}^2. Similarly, \mbox{avg accel for } 1\le t\le 2 = \frac{v(2) - v(1)}{2-1} = 56.73 - 32.73 = 24 \mbox{ft/s}{}^2.

statement.p: Your task is to estimate how far an object traveled during the time interval 0 \leq t \leq 8, but you only have the following data about the velocity of the object.

To get an idea of what the velocity function might look like, you pick up a black pen, plot the data points, and connect them by curves. Your sketch looks something like the black curve in the graph below.

You decide to use a left endpoint Riemann sum to estimate the total displacement. So, you pick up a blue pen and draw rectangles whose height is determined by the velocity measurement at the left endpoint of each one-second interval. By using the left endpoint Riemann sum as an approximation, you are assuming that the actual velocity is approximately constant on each one-second interval (or, equivalently, that the actual acceleration is approximately zero on each one-second interval), and that the velocity and acceleration have discontinuous jumps every second. This assumption is probably incorrect because it is likely that the velocity and acceleration change continuously over time. However, you decide to use this approximation anyway since it seems like a reasonable approximation to the actual velocity given the limited amount of data.
(A) Using the left endpoint Riemann sum, find approximately how far the object traveled. Your answers must include the correct units.
Total displacement =
Total distance traveled =

Using the same data, you also decide to estimate how far the object traveled using a right endpoint Riemann sum. So, you sketch the curve again with a black pen, and draw rectangles whose height is determined by the velocity measurement at the right endpoint of each one-second interval.
(B) Using the right endpoint Riemann sum, find approximately how far the object traveled. Your answers must include the correct units.
Total displacement =
Total distance traveled =

static.solution:
Solution:
Using the left endpoint Riemann sum, the total displacement is the net area of the light blue shaded rectangles, and the total distance is the absolute area of the light blue shaded rectangles.
Total displacement = -4 - 2+3+4+2+3+1+3 = 10 feet.
Total distance = |-4|+|-2|+|3|+|4|+|2|+|3|+|1|+|3| = 22 feet.
We can also make similar calculations using the right endpoint Riemann sum.
Total displacement = -2+3+4+2+3+1+3+1 = 15 feet.
Total distance = |-2|+|3|+|4|+|2|+|3|+|1|+|3|+|1| = 19 feet.

Is the following statement true? \hbox{Average}(f)\cdot\hbox{Average(g)} = \hbox{Average}(f\cdot g)
Yes
No

static.solution:
\int_0^2\,f(x)\,dx and \int_0^2\,g(x)\,dx as the area under the curves and dividing by the length of the interval, which is 2. This gives us:
\hbox{Average}(f) = 0.25, and
\hbox{Average}(g) = 0.25.
However, when we find f(x)\cdot g(x), we find that the product is everywhere zero! g(x) is zero for 0\le x\le 1, so f(x)\cdot g(x) is zero there, and g(x) is zero for 1\le x\le 2, so f(x)\cdot g(x) is zero there too. Thus the average value of the product is zero, and the average of the product is not equal to the product of the averages!

static.solution:
x-axis is greater than the area above the x-axis. We count boxes: The area below the x-axis includes approximately 11.5 boxes and each box has area (2)(1) = 2, so \int_0^5 f(x)dx \approx -23. The area above the x-axis includes approximately 2 boxes, each of area 2, so \int_5^7 f(x)dx \approx 4. So we have \int_0^7 f(x)dx =\int_0^5 f(x)dx+\int_5^7 f(x)dx \approx -23 + 4 = -19.

statement.p: Assume f' is given by the graph below. Suppose f is continuous and that f(5)=0.

p.em: (Click on the graph for a larger version.)

statement.p: Sketch, on a sheet of work paper, an accurate graph of f, and use it to find each of
and
Then find the value of the integral:

p.em: (Note that you can do this in two different ways!)

static.solution:
x=5, we are given that f(5)=0. Moving to the left on the interval 4 \lt x \lt 5, we have f'(x) = -3, and we can find f(4) by knowing that the change in f(x) over this interval is equal to the area under f'(x) between x=4 and x=5. Thus f(5) - f(4) = (-3)(1), so that f(4) = f(5) - (1)(-3) = 3. Similarly, continuing back to x=0, f(0) = f(4) - (1)(3) - (1)(-2) - (2)(1) = 0
Moving to the right from x=5, we know that f'(x) = -3 on 5 \lt x \lt 6. So, as before, f(6) = f(5) + (1)(-3) = -3. Similarly, continuing to x=7, f(7) = f(6) + (1)(1) = -2.
Then, the value of the integral \int_0^7 f'(x)\,dx is given by the sum \int_0^7 f'(x)\,dx = (1)(2) + (-2)(1) + (3)(1) + (-3)(2) + (1)(1) = -2.
Alternatively, knowing f(7)=-2 and f(0)=0 and using the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, we have \int_0^7 f'(x)\,dx=f(7)-f(0) = (-2) - (0) = -2.

interval =
(Give your answer as an interval or a list of intervals, e.g., (-infinity,8] or (1,5),(7,10), or enter none for no intervals.)

static.solution:
A. The definition of g gives g(3) = \int_{3}^{3} f(t)\,dt = 0.
B. The Fundamental Theorem gives g'(5) = f(5) = 2.5.
C. The function g is concave up where g'' is positive. Since g''=f', we see that g is concave up where f is increasing. This occurs on the interval x\in (1.25,6).
D. The function g increases when f is positive and decreases when it is negative, so we're looking for the point at which the greatest positive area is accumulated. Thus g takes its maximum value at x=8.

Find a good numerical approximation to F(2) for the function with the properties that F'(x)=e^{-x^2/5} and F(0)=2.

static.solution: F'(x)=e^{-x^2/5} and F(0)=2, we have F(x)=F(0)+\int_0^x e^{-t^2/5}\,dt = 2 + \int_0^x e^{-t^2/5}\,dt. Substituting x=2 and evaluating the integral numerically gives F(2)=2 + \int_0^{2} e^{-t^2/5}\,dt \approx 3.57363.

statement.p: Find the following integral. Note that you can check your answer by differentiation.

static.solution: w = \ln(z). Then dw = \frac{1}{z}\,dz, so that \int\,\frac{\ln(z)^{6}}{z}\,dz = \int\,w^{6}\,dw = {1\over 7}\,w^{7} + C = {1\over 7}\,(\ln(z))^{7} + C.

statement.p: Find the following integral. Note that you can check your answer by differentiation.

static.solution: w = e^{4 x} + 7. Then dw = 4\,e^{4 x}\,dx, so that \int\,\frac{e^{4 x}}{7 + e^{4 x}}\,dx = {1\over 4}\int\,{1\over w}\,dw = {1\over 4}\,\ln(|w|) + C = {1\over 4}\,\ln(|e^{4 x} + 7|) + C. Because e^{4 x} + 7 is always positive, we can drop the absolute values from the argument of the natural log.

statement.p: Find the following integral. Note that you can check your answer by differentiation.

statement.p: For each of the following integrals, indicate whether integration by substitution or integration by parts is more appropriate, or if neither method is appropriate. Do not evaluate the integrals.

static.solution:
w to be the argument of a function, etc., such that its derivative, dw = w'\,dx, appears in the integrand; or, if the function looks like one on which integration by parts is good. We see that:
1. For \int\,x\sin x\,dx, integration by parts is appropriate, because by taking u = x and v' = \sin(x), we end up with an integral that is easy to find.
2. For \int\,{x^{3}\over 1 + x^{4}}\,dx, substitution is appropriate, because by taking w=1 + x^{4} we get an integral we can find.
3. For \int\,x^{3} e^{x^{4}}\,dx, substitution is appropriate, because by taking w = x^{4} we get an integral we can find.
4. For \int\,x^{3} \cos(x^{4})\,dx, substitution is appropriate, because by taking w = x^{4} we get an integral we can find.
5. For \int\,{1\over\sqrt{2 x + 1}}\,dx, substitution is appropriate, because by taking w = 2 x + 1 we get an integral we can find.

statement.p: Evaluate the definite integral.
Calculate the integral below by partial fractions and by using the indicated substitution. Be sure that you can show how the results you obtain are the same. \int \frac{2x}{x^{2}-16}\,dx
First, rewrite this with partial fractions:
\int \frac{2x}{x^{2}-16}\,dx = \int dx + \int dx = + + C.

p.em: (Note that you should not include the +C in your entered answer, as it has been provided at the end of the expression.)

statement.p: Next, use the substitution w = x^2 - 16 to find the integral:
\int \frac{2x}{x^{2}-16}\,dx = \int dw = + C = + C.

p.em: (For the second answer blank, give your antiderivative in terms of the variable w. Again, note that you should not include the +C in your answer.)

static.solution:
\frac{2x}{x^2-16}=\frac{A}{x+4}+\frac{B}{x-4} so that 2x = A(x-4)+B(x+4) = (A+B)x + 4 (-A+B). Solving, we get A=B=1, so that \int \frac{2x}{x^2-16}\,dx= \int \left(\frac{1}{x+4}+\frac{1}{x-4}\right)\,dx =\ln|x+4|+\ln|x-4|+C.
Using the substitution w=x^2-16, we get dw= 2x\,dx, so we have \int \frac{2x}{x^2-16}\,dx= \int \frac{dw}{w}=\ln|w|+C = \ln|x^2-16|+C.
The properties of logarithms show that the two results are the same: \ln|x+4|+\ln|x-4| = \ln|(x+4)(x-4)| =\ln|x^2-16|.

statement.p: Calculate the integral:

static.solution: \frac{1}{(x+6)(x+8)}=\frac{A}{x+6}+\frac{B}{x+8}, giving 1 = A(x+8)+B(x+6), or 1 = (A+B)x+ (8 A+6 B). Solving for A and B, we find A = 0.5 and B = -0.5, so \int \frac{1}{(x+6)(x+8)}\,dx= \int\frac{0.5}{x+6}\,dx + \int \frac{-0.5}{x+8}\,dx = 0.5\ln\!\left(\left|x+6\right|\right)-0.5\ln\!\left(\left|x+8\right|\right)+C.

statement.p: Calculate the integral

static.solution: \frac{7 x + 4}{x^2-3x+2} = \frac{7 x+4}{(x-1)(x-2)} = \frac{A}{x-1} + \frac{B}{x-2}. Multiplying by (x-1) and (x-2), this becomes 7 x+4 = A(x-2)+B(x-1), or A+B = 7 \quad\hbox{and}\quad -2A - B = 4. Solving this system yields A = -11 and B = 18. Then \int\frac{7 x+4}{x^2-3x+2}dx = \int\left(\frac{18}{x-2} - \frac{11}{x-1}\right)\,dx = 18\ln\!\left(\left|x-2\right|\right)-11\ln\!\left(\left|x-1\right|\right)+C.

statement.p: Consider the following indefinite integral. \int \frac{4 x^3+ 8 x^2+ 75 x+ 150 }{x^4+25 x^2}\, dx
The integrand has partial fractions decomposition:
\frac{a}{x^2} + \frac{b}{x} + \frac{cx + d}{x^2+25} where
Now integrate term by term to evaluate the integral.
Answer: +C
The form of the partial fraction decomposition of a rational function is given below.
Now evaluate the indefinite integral.

solution.p: SOLUTION

Multiplying by the least common denominator gives 3x^{2}+4x+47 = A(x^2+9)+(Bx+C)(x+5) Rearranging terms on the right hand side, yields 3x^{2}+4x+47 = (A+B)x^2+(5B+C)x + 9 A+ 5C Now we equate the coefficients: \begin{array}{rl} A+B \amp = 3 \\ 5B +C \amp = 4 \\ 9 A + 5C \amp = 47 \end{array} Solving the system gives A=3, \; B = 0 and C= 4 so the partial fraction decomposition is \frac{3x^{2}+4x+47}{(x+5)(x^2+9)} = \frac{3}{x+5} + \frac{4}{x^2+9} The definite integral is then \displaystyle \int \frac{3x^{2}+4x+47}{(x+5)(x^2+9)} dx = 3\ln\!\left(\left|x+5\right|\right) + \frac{4\tan^{-1}\!\left(\frac{x}{3}\right)}{3} +C

statement.p: (a) What is the exact value of \int_{0}^{3}\,e^x\,dx?
Find LEFT(2), RIGHT(2), TRAP(2), MID(2), and SIMP(2); compute the error for each.
Repeat part (b) with n=4 (instead of n=2).
For each rule in part (b), as n goes from n=2 to n=4, does the error go down approximately as you would expect? Explain by calculating the ratios of the errors:
Error LEFT(2)/Error LEFT(4) =
Error RIGHT(2)/Error RIGHT(4) =
Error TRAP(2)/Error TRAP(4) =
Error MID(2)/Error MID(4) =
Error SIMP(2)/Error SIMP(4) =

p.em: (Be sure that you can explain in words why these do (or don't) make sense.)

static.solution:
(a) \int_{0}^{3}\,e^x\,dx = e^x\bigg|_{0}^{3} = e^3 - e^0 \approx 19.0855\ldots
(b) Computing the sums directly, since \Delta x=1.5, we have
LEFT(2) = 1.5\cdot e^0 + 1.5\cdot e^{1.5} \approx 8.2225
RIGHT(2) = 1.5\cdot e^{1.5} + 1.5\cdot e^{3} \approx 36.8509
TRAP(2) = \frac 1 2 ( 8.2225 + 36.8509 ) \approx 22.5367
MID(2) = 1.5\cdot e^{0.75} + 1.5\cdot e^{3\cdot 0.75} \approx 17.4072
and SIMP(2) = (2 MID(2) + TRAP(2))/3 \approx 19.117.
And the errors are just the actual value minus the approximate values, or
error(LEFT(2)) = 10.863; error(RIGHT(2)) = -17.7654; error(TRAP(2)) = -3.4512; error(MID(2)) = 1.6784; and error(SIMP(2)) = -0.0315.
(c) Similarly, since \Delta x = 0.375, we have
LEFT(4) = 12.8149; error = 6.2707
RIGHT(4) = 27.129; error = -8.0435
TRAP(4) = 19.9719; error = -0.8864
MID(4) = 18.6455; error = 0.44
SIMP(4) = 19.0876; error = -0.0021.
(d) For LEFT and RIGHT, we expect the error to go down by 1/2, and this is very roughly what we see. For MID and TRAP, we expect the error to go down by 1/4, and this is approximately what we see. For SIMP, we expect the error to go down by 1/16, again as observed.

statement.p: Find the area between y = 6 \sin x and y = 9 \cos x over the interval \left[0,\pi\right]. Sketch the curves if necessary.

static.solution:
Over the interval [0,\pi], the graphs y = 6\sin x and y = 9 \cos x intersect when 6\sin x = 9 \cos x, i.e., \tan x = \frac{9}{6}, i.e., x=\tan^{-1}(\frac{9}{6})=0.982793723247329.
Let t = \tan^{-1}(\frac{9}{6}).
Over the interval \left[0, t\right], the graph of y = 6\sin x lies below that of y = 9 \cos x. Hence, the area between the two curves is \int_0^{ t}(9 \cos x-6 \sin x)dx \begin{array}{ll} \amp =\left.(9\sin x+6\cos x)\right|_0^{ t} \cr \amp =\left(9\sin t+6\cos t\right)-(9\cdot 0+6\cdot 1)\cr \amp =\left(9\sin t+6\cos t\right)-6 \end{array}
Since t = \tan^{-1}(\frac{9}{6}), we have \tan t = \frac{9}{6}. Considering a rightangle triangle with an angle which opposite side has length 9 and adjacent side has length 6, we see that the hypotenues is \sqrt{117}. Thus \sin t = \frac{9}{\sqrt{117}} and \cos t = \frac{6}{\sqrt{117}}.
9\sin t+6\cos t = \frac{9^2}{\sqrt{117}} + \frac{6^2}{\sqrt{117}} = \frac{9^2+6^2}{\sqrt{117}} = \frac{117}{\sqrt{117}}=\sqrt{117}.
Thus, \int_0^{ t}(9 \cos x-6 \sin x)dx= \sqrt{117}-6.
Over the interval \left[ t,\pi\right], the graph of y = 6\sin x lies above that of y = 9 \cos x. Hence, the area between the two curves is \int^\pi_{ t}(6\sin x - 9 \cos x)dx \begin{array}{ll} \amp =-\left.(9\sin x+6\cos x)\right|^\pi_{ t} \cr \amp =6 + \sqrt{117} \end{array}
Thus the total area is the sum of the above two integrals, which is 2\sqrt{117}.

statement.p: Find the volume of the solid obtained by rotating the region in the first quadrant bounded by y=x^{6}, y=1, and the y-axis around the x-axis.

static.solution: \Delta x, outer radius y=1 and inner radius y=x^{6}. Therefore, \hbox{Volume of slice }\approx \pi 1^2\Delta x-\pi y^2\Delta x = \pi(1-x^{12})\, \Delta x. Therefore, \hbox{Volume of solid } = \lim_{\Delta x\to0} \Sigma \pi(1-x^{12})\,\Delta x = \int_0^1\pi(1-x^{12})\, dx =\pi\left(x-\frac{x^{13}}{13}\right)\Bigg|_0^1 = \pi(1 - {1\over 13}) = {12\over13} \pi.

statement.p: Find the volume of the solid obtained by rotating the region in the first quadrant bounded by y=x^{6}, y=1, and the y-axis about the line y=-5.
Volume =

static.solution: y=-5. We slice it into rings vertically. A typical ring has thickness \Delta x, outer radius 1+5=6, and inner radius y+5=x^{6}+5. Thus \hbox{Volume of slice }\approx \pi 6^2\Delta x - \pi(x^{6}+5)^2\Delta x = \pi(11 - x^{12} - 10 x^{6})\, \Delta x. Therefore, we have \hbox{Volume of solid } = \int_0^1\pi(11 - x^{12} - 10 x^{6})\,dx = \pi \left(11 x - \frac{x^{13}}{13} - {10\over 7} x^{7}\right)\Bigg|_0^1 = \pi ( 11 - {1\over 13} - {10\over 7} ).

A rod has length 5 meters. At a distance x meters from its left end, the density of the rod is given by \delta(x)=4 + 6 x g/m.
(a) Complete the Riemann sum for the total mass of the rod (use Dx in place of \Delta x):
mass = \Sigma
(b) Convert the Riemann sum to an integral and find the exact mass.
mass =
(include units)

static.solution:
(a) Suppose we choose an x, 0\leq x\leq 5. If \Delta x is a small fraction of a meter, then the density of the rod is approximately \delta(x) anywhere from x to x+\Delta x meters from the left end of the rod. The mass of the rod from x to x+\Delta x meters is therefore approximately \delta(x) \Delta x = (4 + 6 x)\Delta x. If we slice the rod into N pieces, then a Riemann sum is \Sigma_{i=1}^{N}(4 + 6 x_i)\Delta x, or, more loosely, \Sigma (4 + 6 x)\Delta x.
(b) The definite integral is M=\int_0^{5} \delta(x)\,dx = \int_0^{5} (4 + 6 x)\,dx= (4 x + 3 x^2)\bigg|_0^{5} = 95 \hbox{ grams}.

li.p: Find the average velocity over the interval 0 \le t \le 0.2.
The average velocity over the interval 0 \le t \le 0.2 is given by \frac{s(0.2)-s(0)}{0.2}=\frac{0.5}{0.2}=2.5\text{ ft/s}.
The average velocity over the interval 0.2 \le t \le 0.4 is given by \frac{s(0.4)-s(0.2)}{0.2}=\frac{1.4-0.5}{0.2}=4.5\text{ ft/s}.
A reasonable estimate for the velocity at (t=0.2) is the average \frac{1}{2}\cdot (2.5+4.5) = 3.5\text{ ft/s}.

statement.p: Suppose that the density of cars (in cars per mile) down a 20-mile stretch of the Pennsylvania Turnpike is approximated by \delta(x) = 350 \left(2+\sin\left(4\sqrt{x + 0.1}\right)\right), at a distance x miles from the Breezewood toll plaza. Sketch a graph of this function for 0\leq x\leq 20.
(a) Complete the Riemann sum that approximates the total number of cars on this 20-mile stretch (use Dx instead of \Delta x):
Number = \Sigma
(b) Find the total number of cars on the 20-mile stretch.
Number =

static.solution:
(a) Suppose we choose an x, 0\le x\le 20. We approximate the density of the number of the cars between x and x+\Delta x miles as \delta(x) cars per mile. Therefore, the number of cars between x and x+\Delta x is approximately \delta(x)\Delta x. If we slice the 20 mile strip into N slices, we get that the total number of cars is C \approx \Sigma_{i=1}^N \delta(x_i)\Delta x = \Sigma_{i=1}^N \left[ 700 + 350\sin(4\sqrt{x_i + 0.1})\right]\Delta x, where \Delta x =20/N. This is a right-hand approximation; the corresponding left-hand approximation is \Sigma_{i=0}^{N-1}\delta(x_i)\Delta x. We can more loosely write both approximations without referring to the number of steps as C \approx \Sigma \left[ 700 + 350\sin(4\sqrt{x + 0.1})\right]\Delta x.
(b) As N\to\infty, the Riemann sum above approaches the integral C =\int_0^{20} (700 + 350\sin4\sqrt{x + 0.1})\,dx. If we calculate the integral numerically, we find C\approx 13462.6. We can also find the integral exactly as follows: C = \int_0^{20} (700 + 350\sin4\sqrt{x +0.1})\,dx = \int_0^{20} 700\,dx +\int_0^{20} 350\sin4\sqrt{x + 0.1}\,dx = 14000 + 350\int_0^{20}\sin4\sqrt{x +0.1}\,dx. Let w = \sqrt{x +0.1}, so x =w^2 -0.1 and dx =2w\,dw. Then \int_{x=0}^{x=20}\sin 4\sqrt{x +0.1}\,dx = 2\int_{w=\sqrt{0.1}}^{w=\sqrt{20.1}} w\sin 4w\,dw, = 2\left[-{1\over 4}w\cos 4w +{1\over 16}\sin 4w\right] \bigg|_{\sqrt{0.1}}^{\sqrt{20.1}} \approx -1.419. (To find the integral we used the appropriate entry in a table of integrals.) Using this, we have C\approx 14000 + 350(-1.419) \approx 13462.6, which matches our numerical approximation.

A tank in the shape of an inverted right circular cone has height 4 meters and radius 3 meters. It is filled with 3 meters of hot chocolate. Find the work required to empty the tank by pumping the hot chocolate over the top of the tank. The density of hot chocolate is \delta = 1060 \ \textrm{kg}/\textrm{m}^3. Your answer must include the correct units.
Work =

solution.p: SOLUTION

We think of the tank as made from infinitely many 'infinitesimal' horizontal slices, with x the vertical distance an infinitesimal slice of the water is from the bottom of the tank (the vertex of the right circular cone).
A cross section through the vertical center to the side is approximated below (not necessarily to scale).

Now the large right triangle with height 4 and top side length 3 is similar to the right triangle with height x and top side length r. So \frac{4}{3} = \frac{x}{r}\implies 4 r = 3 x or r = {\frac{3}{4}} x.
Therefore the area of every infinitesimal slice is A(x) = \pi(r)^2=\pi({\frac{3}{4}} x)^2={\frac{9}{16}} \pi x^2 \text{meter}^2.

The infinitesimal slice has volume dV=A(x)dx = {\frac{9}{16}} \pi x^2\,dx \text{meter}^3, and since mass = density\times volume, the mass of our infinitesimal slice is dm = \delta dV where \delta= 1060 \frac{kg}{\text{meter}^3}.
So the mass of the slice at x is \delta\,dV= (1060)\left({\frac{9}{16}} \pi x^2\right)\,dx kg. We now must find mgh for each slice.
Each slice at x must be lifted a height h = (4-x) meters, and g=9.8 \frac{meters}{sec^2} . So mgh for each slice is 9.8(1060)\left({\frac{9}{16}} \pi x^2\right)(4-x)\,dx Joules.

statement.p: A fuel oil tank is an upright cylinder, buried so that its circular top is 8 feet beneath ground level. The tank has a radius of 8 feet and is 24 feet high, although the current oil level is only 23 feet deep. Calculate the work required to pump all of the oil to the surface. Oil weighs 50\, \hbox{lb/ft}^3.
Work =
(include units)

static.solution:
h below the surface with thickness \Delta h. We can then calculate the volume of the slab and the work needed to raise this slab to the surface, a distance of h. \hbox{Volume of slab } = \pi r^2\Delta h = 64 \pi \Delta h
\hbox{Distance to raise } = h
\hbox{Work to raise } = (64 \pi)(50)(h) \Delta h.
Integrating the work over all such slabs, we have \hbox{Work} = \int_{9}^{32} (50)(64\pi)(h) \,dh = 1600\pi h^2{\bigg|}_{9}^{32} = 1508800 \pi \hbox{ lbf}.

statement.p: A rectangular swimming pool 40 ft long, 25 ft wide, and 10 ft deep is filled with water to a depth of 7 ft. Use an integral to find the work required to pump all the water out over the top. (Take as the density of water \delta = 62.4 \hbox{lb/ft}^3.)
Work =
(include units)

static.solution:
h ft above the bottom, a slice of thickness \Delta h has \hbox{Volume }\approx 40\cdot 25\Delta h \hbox{ ft}{}^3. Since the density of water is \rho lb/ft{}^3, \hbox{Weight of the slice }\approx\rho(40 \cdot 25 \cdot \Delta h) \hbox{ lbs}. The distance to lift the slice of water at height h ft is 10 - h ft, so the work to move one slice, \Delta W, is \Delta W = \rho \cdot \hbox{Volume} \cdot \hbox{Distance lifted} \approx \rho(40 \cdot 25 \cdot \Delta h)(10 - h) = 1000 \rho (10 - h) \Delta h\hbox{ ft-lb}.
The work done, W, to pump all the water is the sum of the work done on the pieces: W \approx \Sigma\, 1000 \rho(10-h)\Delta h. As \Delta h \rightarrow 0, we obtain a definite integral. Since h varies from h = 0 to h = 7 and \rho=62.4\hbox{ lb/ft}{}^3, the total work is: W = \int_0^{7} 62400 (10-h)dh = 62400 \left(10 h - {h^2\over 2}\right)\bigg|_0^{7} = 62400 (45.5) = 2839200\, \hbox{lbf}.

statement.p: Water in a cylinder of height 10 ft and radius 4 ft is to be pumped out. The density of water is 62.4 lb/ft{}^3. Find the work required if
(a) The tank is full of water and the water is to be pumped over the top of the tank.
Work =
(include units)
(b) The tank is full of water and the water must be pumped to a height 5 ft above the top of the tank.
Work =
(include units)
(c) The depth of water in the tank is 8 ft and the water must be pumped over the top of the tank.
Work =
(include units)

static.solution:
(a) We slice the water horizontally. Each slice is a cylindrical slab of radius and thickness \Delta h, so
\hbox{Volume of each slab }\approx \pi 4^2 \Delta h\hbox{ ft}^3. The density of water is \delta = 62.4 lb/ft{}^3, so \hbox{Weight of slab }\approx \delta\pi4^2 \Delta h \hbox{ lb.} Water at a height of h ft must be lifted a distance of 10 - h ft. \hbox{ Work to move one slice} =\delta \cdot \hbox{Volume} \cdot \hbox{Distance lifted} \approx \delta (\pi (4)^2 \Delta h)(10 - h)\hbox{ ft-lb.} Plugging in \delta=62.4 and since h varies from h = 0 to h = 10, the total work, W, is: W = \int_0^{10}{\delta(\pi 4^2 )(10-h)dh} = 4^2\delta \pi \int_0^{10}{(10 - h)dh} = (4^2) 62.4 \pi\left(10 h-\frac{h^2}2\right) \Bigg|_0^{10} = 156828\ {\rm lbf}. The total work required is 156828\ {\rm lbf}.
(b) This is the same as part (a) except the water must be lifted a distance of 15 - h ft. The total work is: W = \int_0^{10}{\delta(\pi 4^2 )(5-h)dh} = 4^2\delta \pi \int_0^{10}{(15 - h)dh} = (4^2) 62.4 \pi \left(15 h-\frac{h^2}2\right)\Bigg|_0^{10} = 313657\ {\rm lbf}. The total work required is 313657\ {\rm lbf}.
(c) This is the same as part (a) except that h varies from h=0 to h=8. The total work is: W = \int_0^{8}{\delta(\pi 4^2 )(10-h)dh} = 4^2\delta \pi \int_0^{8}{(10 -h)dh} = (4^2) 62.4 \pi \left(10 h-\frac{h^2}2\right)\Bigg|_0^{10} = 150555\ {\rm lbf}. The total work required is 150555\ {\rm lbf}.

statement.p: Consider the integral \int_{0}^{\,3} {\frac{6}{x\sqrt{x}}}\, dx If the integral is divergent, type an upper-case "D". Otherwise, evaluate the integral.
Calculate the integral below, if it converges. If it does not converge, enter diverges for your answer.

static.solution: \int_{2}^{\infty} 2x^{2}e^{-x^{3}} dx = \lim_{b \rightarrow \infty} \int_{2}^b 2x^{2}e^{-x^{3}} dx = \left.\lim_{b \rightarrow \infty} \left({{-2} \over 3} e^{-x^3}\right) \right|_0^b = \lim_{b \rightarrow \infty} \left({{-2} \over 3} e^{-b^3} - {{-2} \over 3} e^{-2^3}\right) = 0 + {2\over 3} e^{-8} = {2\over 3} e^{-8}. This integral converges to {2\over 3} e^{-8}.

statement.p: Calculate the integral, if it converges. If it diverges, enter diverges for your answer.

static.solution: w = 1 + e^{5 x}, we have \int_{-\infty}^{3}\,{e^{5 x}\over 1 + e^{5 x}}\,dx = \lim\limits_{b\to 1^{+}} \int_b^{1 + e^{15}} {1\over 5}{dw\over w} = \lim\limits_{b\to 1^{+}} {1\over 5}(\ln(1 + e^{15}) - \ln(b)) = {1\over 5}\ln(1 + e^{15}).

statement.p: The table below shows the number of calories used per minute as a function of an individuals body weight for three sports:

li.p: Determine the number of calories that a 200 lb person uses in one half-hour of walking.
Who uses more calories, a 170 lb person swimming for one hour, or a 220 lb person bicycling for a half-hour?
The 170 lb person swimming for one hour
The 220 lb person bicycling for a half-hour
They both use the same amount of calories
Does the number of calories of a person walking increase or decrease as weight increases?

The table gives the amount of calories used per minute. So in order to find the total number of calories used in a half-hour, use the table to find the number of calories used by a 200 lb who walks for a half-hour, and then multiply by 30 minutes. Using the table we know a 200 lb person walking uses 5.4 calories per minute; therefore, \text{Total calories used} = ( 5.4 )(30) = 162

Using the same calculation as in (a), it follows that a 170 lb person swimming uses 9.8 calories per minute. Thus a 170 lb person swimming for one hour uses a total of ( 9.8 )(60) = 588 calories. On the other hand, a 220 lb person bicycling uses 11.9 calories per minute. Thus a 220 lb person bicycling for a half-hour uses a total of ( 11.9 )(30) = 357 calories. By comparing the values 588 and 357 we obtain the answer.
Since the values in the table are increasing along the row of values corresponding to a person who is walking, the number of calories of a person walking increases as weight increases.

statement.p: Calculate the integral, if it converges. If it diverges, enter diverges for your answer.

static.solution: 1/v is undefined at v=0. To evaluate it, we must split the region of integration up into two pieces, from 0 to 8 and from -8 to 0. But notice, \int_0^{8}{1\over v}\, dv = \lim_{b\to 0^+}\int_b^{8} {1\over v}\, dv = \lim_{b\to 0^+}\left({\ln v}\bigg|_b^{8}\right) = \ln(8) - \ln b. As b\to 0^+, this goes to infinity and the integral diverges, so our original integral also diverges.

statement.p: Find the area under the curve y = {1\over\cos^2(t)} between t = 0 and t = \pi/2. Enter diverges if the area is not bounded.
area =

static.solution:
\int_0^{\pi/2}\,{1\over\cos^2(t)}\,dt. However, the integrand is undefined at t = \pi/2, so this is an improper integral. We find \int_0^{\pi/2}\,{1\over\cos^2(t)}\,dt = \lim\limits_{a\to\pi/2^{-}}\,\int_0^a\,{1\over\cos^2(t)}\,dt = \lim\limits_{a\to\pi/2^{-}}\,(\tan(t))\bigg|_0^a = \lim\limits_{a\to\pi/2^{-}}( \tan(a) - \tan(0) ). However, \tan(a) is undefined as a\to\pi/2, so this integral diverges.
Thus, because the integral diverges, the area is not bounded.

statement.p: Match the solutions to the differential equations. If there is more than one solution to an equation, select the answer that includes all solutions.

li.p: y = e^{-3 x} or y = e^{3 x}

static.solution:
\frac{d}{dx} (e^{-3 x}) = -3 e^{-3 x},
\frac{d^2}{dx^2} (e^{-3 x}) = 9 e^{-3 x},
\frac{d}{dx} (e^{3 x}) = 3 e^{-3 x},
\frac{d^2}{dx^2} (e^{-3 x}) = 9 e^{-3 x},
\frac{d}{dx} (\sin(3 x)) = 3 \cos(3 x),
\frac{d^2}{dx^2} (\sin(3 x)) = -9 \sin(3 x),
\frac{d}{dx} (3 \sin(x)) = 3 \cos(x), and
\frac{d^2}{dx^2} (3 \sin(x)) = -3 \sin(3 x).
Thus, the correct answers are:
\frac{dy}{dx}=-3 y : B,
\frac{dy}{dx}=3 y : C,
\frac{d^2y}{dx^2}=9 y : F, and
\frac{d^2y}{dx^2}=-9 y : A

statement.p: Find a positive value of k for which y = \cos(k t) satisfies \frac{d^2y}{dt^2} + 4 y = 0.

static.solution: y=\cos(k t), then \frac{d^2y}{dt^2}=-k^2 \cos(k t), and so we need k such that \frac{d^2y}{dt^2} + 4 y =-k^2 \cos(2t) + 4 \cos(2t)=0. Thus k = 2.

statement.p: Let A and k be positive constants.

static.solution: \frac{d}{dt} (A + C e^{-kt}) = -k C e^{-kt}, so that, plugging in, we have -k C e^{-kt} = k(A - A + Ce^{-kt}), a true statement, so that the correct answer is y = A + C e^{-kt}.

static.solution:
y' = -x-y with y(-1)=0:
x y \Delta y =(slope)\Delta x
1 1 -0.2 = (-2)(0.1)

statement.p: Use Euler's method to solve \frac{dB}{dt}= 0.03 B with initial value B=1300 when t=0 .
A. \Delta t = 1 and 1 step: B(1) \approx
B. \Delta t = 0.5 and 2 steps: B(1) \approx
C. \Delta t = 0.25 and 4 steps: B(1) \approx

D. Suppose B is the balance in a bank account earning interest. Be sure that you can explain why the result of your calculation in part (a) is equivalent to compounding the interest once a year instead of continuously. Then interpret the result of your calculations in parts (b) and (c) in terms of compound interest.

static.solution:
A. With one step of \Delta t = 1, we have
B(1) \approx 1300 + (1)(0.03)(1300) = 1339.
B. With two steps of \Delta t = 0.5, we have
B(0.5) \approx 1300 + (0.5)(0.03)(1300) = 1319.5,
B(1) \approx 1319.5 + (0.5)(0.03)(1319.5) = 1339.2925.
Note that we can simplify this some: B(0.5) \approx (1 + \frac{0.03}{2}) (1300), so that B(1) \approx B(0.5) + \frac{0.03}{2} B(0.5) = (1 + \frac{0.03}{2})^2 (1300).
C. With four steps of \Delta t = 0.25, we have, following the pattern we saw in (B),
B(0.25) \approx 1300 + (0.25)(0.03)(1300) = (1 + \frac{0.03}{4}) (1300),
B(0.5) \approx B(0.25) + (0.25)(0.03) B(0.25) = (1 + \frac{0.03}{4})^2 (1300),
B(0.75) \approx B(0.5) + (0.25)(0.03) B(0.5) = (1 + \frac{0.03}{4})^3 (1300), and B(1) \approx B(0.75) + (0.25)(0.03) B(0.75) = (1 + \frac{0.03}{4})^4 (1300) = 1339.441.
D. In part (A), we get our approximation by making a single increment, \Delta B, where \Delta B is just 0.03 B. If we think in terms of interest, \Delta B is just like getting one end of the year interest payment. Since \Delta B is 0.03 times the balance B, it is like getting 39 dollars.
Part (B) is equivalent to computing the final amount in an account that begins with 1300 dollars and earns 39 dollars twice annually. Each step is like computing the interest after 6 months. When t=0.5, for example, the interest is \Delta B=(0.03 B)\cdot\frac{1}{2}, and we add this to 1300 dollars to get the new balance.
Similarly, part (C) is equivalent to the final amount in an account that has an initial balance of 1300 dollars and earns 39 dollars compounded quarterly.

statement.p: Find the equation of the solution to \displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx} = x^{4} y through the point (x,y) = (1,3).
Find the solution to the differential equation \frac{dy}{dt} = 0.4 (y - 100) if y=35 when t=0.

static.solution: \int\frac{dy}{y-100} = \int 0.4 dt, so \ln|y-100| = 0.4 t +C. Solving for y, y = 100 + A e^{0.4 t}, where A = \pm e^C. The initial condition, y(0)=35, gives 35 = 100 + A, so A = 65, and y= 100 - 65 e^{0.4 t}.

statement.p: Find the solution to the differential equation \frac{dy}{dt} = y^2(4 + t), y=6 when t=1.

static.solution: \frac{dy}{y^2} = (4 + t)\,dt, so \int \frac{dy}{y^2} = \int (4 + t)\,dt, and -\frac{1}{y} = {1\over2}(4 + t)^2 + C, giving y=-\frac{2}{(4 + t)^2 + A}, where A = 2C. Since y=6 when t=1, we have 6 = -\frac{2}{5^2 + A},\quad \hbox{ so } \quad 6 A + 150 = -2, and A = -{{76\over3}}. Thus y = -\frac{2}{(4 + t)^2 - {{76\over3}}}.

both have an equal rate of change

solution.p: Since the graph of g(x) is a line, its average rate of change is the same over all intervals. Since the graph of g(x) is going up, its average rate of change is always positive. The average rate of change of f(x) is clearly changing depending on the interval. If the slope of the line connecting the two endpoints of the interval on f(x) is going up and is steeper than the slope of g(x), then the average rate of change of f(x) will be greater over that interval. If the line connecting the two endpoints points on f(x) is less steep, horizontal, or going down, then the average rate of change of g(x) will greater over that interval. If the slope of the line connecting to endpoints of the interval on f(x) is the same as the slope of g(x), then the two average rates of change will be equal (such as the case for the interval 2.2 \leq x \leq 6.1. static.solution:
Thus we get different solution behaviors for the initial conditions P(0) = 1.5, P(0) > 1.5, and 0 \lt P(0) \lt 1.5. The initial condition P(0) = 0 gives the zero solution, which is an equilibrium and has the same behavior as the initial condition P(0) = 1.5. Note that we can also say that the behavior for initial conditions 0 \lt P(0) \lt 0.75 is different from that for initial conditions 0.75 \le P(0) \lt 1.5, because the former will be sigmoidal while the latter are strictly exponential.
From the solutions graphed above, or by looking at the slope field, we can see that the equilibrium solution P = 1.5 is stable. The other equilibrium solution, P = 0 is unstable.
Also by looking at the solution curves, we can see that P is increasing when 0 \lt P \lt 1.5 and decreasing when P > 1.5. In the long run, we're most likely to start with a non-zero population and thus P\to 1.5. The solution curves with initial populations of less than P= 0.75 have inflection points at P=0.75. (This will be demonstrated algebraically below.) At the inflection point, the population is growing fastest.
A graph of dP/dt against P is shown below.
Since \frac{dP}{dt}=4.5 P - 3 P^2 = 3 P(1.5 - P), the graph of \frac{dP}{dt} against P is a parabola, opening downward with P intercepts at 0 and 1.5. The quantity \frac{dP}{dt} is positive for 0 \lt P \lt 1.5, negative for P > 1.5 (and P \lt 0). The quantity \frac{dP}{dt} is 0 at P=0 and P=, and maximum at P=0.75. The fact that \frac{dP}{dt} =0 at P=0 and P=1.5 tells us that these are equilibria. Further, since \frac{dP}{dt}> 0 for 0 \lt P \lt 1.5, we see that solution curves starting here will increase toward P=1.5.
If the population starts at a value P\lt 0.75, it increases at an increasing rate up to P=0.75. After this, P continues to increase, but at a decreasing rate. The fact that \frac{dP}{dt} has a maximum at P=0.75 tells us that there is a point of inflection when P=0.75. Similarly, since \frac{dP}{dt} \lt 0 for P > 1.5, solution curves starting with P > 1 will decrease to P = 1.5. Thus, P=1.5 is a stable equilibrium.

statement.p: The table below gives the percentage, P, of households with a VCR, as a function of year.

(a) A logistic model is a good one to use for these data. Explain why this might be the case: logically, how large would the growth in VCR ownership be when they are first introduced? How large can the ownership ever be?
We can also investigate this by estimating the growth rate of P for the given data. Do this at the beginning, middle, and near the end of the data:
Be sure you can explain why this suggests that a logistic model is appropriate.
(b) Use the data to estimate the year when the point of inflection of P occurs.
The inflection point occurs approximately at .

statement.p: What percent of households had VCRs then? P =
What limiting value L does this point of inflection predict (note that if the logistic model is reasonable, this prediction should agree with the data for 1990 and 1991)?
(c) The best logistic equation (solution to the logistic differential equation) for these data turns out to be the following. P=\frac{75}{1+316.75e^{-0.699t}}.
What limiting value does this predict?

static.solution:
(a) The logistic model is a reasonable one because at first very few houses have a VCR. As movie rentals become popular and as VCRs get cheaper, more people will buy VCRs. However, we know that the rate of VCR buying will start slowing down at some point as it is impossible for more than 100
(b) To find the point of inflection, we must find the year at which the rate of VCR buying changes from increasing to decreasing. The following table shows the rate of change =(P(y+1)-P(y))/1 in the years from 1978 to 1990.
Year 1978 1979 1980 1981 1982 1983 1984
Change per year 0.2 0.6 0.7 1.3 2.4 5.1 10.2
Year 1985 1986 1987 1988 1989 1990 1991
Change per year 15.2 12.7 9.3 6.6 7.3 0
Looking at the table, we see that the rate of percent change per year changes from increasing to decreasing in the year 1986. At this time (at the inflection point) we expect the vertical coordinate to be L/2, one-half of the limiting value for the population. Thus we have L/2 = 36, or L = 72, which fits in well with the data that we have for 1990 and 1991.
(c) Since the general form of a logistic equation is P=\frac{L}{1+Ce^{-kt}} where L is the limiting value, we have that in our case L=75 and the limiting value is 75.

statement.p: The total number of people infected with a virus often grows like a logistic curve. Suppose that 20 people originally have the virus, and that in the early stages of the virus (with time, t, measured in weeks), the number of people infected is increasing exponentially with k=1.6. It is estimated that, in the long run, approximately 7250 people become infected.
(a) Use this information to find a logistic function to model this situation.

(b) Sketch a graph of your answer to part (a). Use your graph to estimate the length of time until the rate at which people are becoming infected starts to decrease. What is the vertical coordinate at this point?
vertical coordinate =

static.solution:
(a) We know that a logistic curve can be modeled by the function P=\frac{L}{1+Ce^{-kt}} where C=(L-P_0)/P_0 and P is the number of people infected by the virus at a particular time t. We know that L is the limiting value, or the maximal number of people infected with the virus, so in our case L=7250. We are also told that initially there are only 20 people infected with the virus so that we get P_0=20. Thus we have C = \frac{L-P_0}{P_0} = \frac{7250-20}{20} = 361.5. We are also told that in the early stages of the virus, infection grows exponentially with k=1.6. Thus we get that the logistic function for people infected is P=\frac{7250}{1+361.5 e^{-1.6 t}}.
(b) Graphing this solution, we see
Looking at the graph we see that the the point at which the rate changes from increasing to decreasing, the inflection point, occurs at roughly t=3.75 giving a value of P=3750. Thus after roughly 3750 people have been infected, the rate of infection starts dropping.

statement.p: Any population, P, for which we can ignore immigration, satisfies \frac{dP}{dt} =\hbox{Birth rate} - \hbox{Death rate}.

For organisms which need a partner for reproduction but rely on a chance encounter for meeting a mate, the birth rate is proportional to the square of the population. Thus, the population of such a type of organism satisfies a differential equation of the form \frac{dP}{dt} = a P^2 - b P\quad\hbox{with } a,\,b>0. This problem investigates the solutions to such an equation.
(a) Sketch a graph of dP/dt against P. Note when dP/dt is positive and negative.
dP/dt \lt 0 when P is in
dP/dt > 0 when P is in

p.em: (Your answers may involve a and b. Give your answers as an interval or list of intervals: thus, if dP/dt is less than zero for P between 1 and 3 and P greater than 4, enter (1,3),(4,infinity).)

statement.p: (b) Use this graph to sketch the shape of solution curves with various initial values: use your answers in part (a), and where dP/dt is increasing and decreasing to decide what the shape of the curves has to be. Based on your solution curves, why is P=b/a called the threshold population?
If P(0) > b/a, what happens to P in the long run?
If P(0) = b/a, what happens to P in the long run?
If P(0) \lt b/a, what happens to P in the long run?

static.solution:
(a) A graph of dP/dt vs P is shown below.
Thus, dP/dt is negative when 0 \lt P \lt b/a and positive when b/a \lt P \lt \infty (we ignore P \lt 0, because this doesn't make sense for a population).
(b)
We can see from the graph above that P is a decreasing function when P\lt \frac{b}{a}. Similarly, when P>\frac{b}{a}, the sign of dP/dt is positive, so P is an increasing function. Thus solution curves starting above \frac{b}{a} are increasing, and those starting below \frac{b}{a} are decreasing.
We can also see that for P>\frac{b}{a}, the slope, \frac{dP}{dt}, increases with P, so the graph of P against t is concave up. For 0\lt P\lt \frac{b}{a}, the value of P decreases with time. As P decreases, the slope \frac{dP}{dt} decreases for \frac{b}{2a}\lt P\lt \frac{b}{a}, and increases toward 0 for 0\lt P\lt \frac{b}{2a}. Thus solution curves starting just below the threshold value of \frac{b}{a} are concave down for \frac{b}{2a}\lt P\lt \frac{b}{a} and concave up and asymptotic to the t-axis for 0\lt P\lt \frac{b}{2a}. Thus, solution curves are similar to those shown in the graph below
P=\frac{b}{a} is called the threshold population because for populations greater than \frac{b}{a}, the population will increase without bound. For populations less than \frac{b}{a}, the population will go to zero, i.e. to extinction. The value \frac{b}{a} is an unstable equilibrium, and P=0 is a stable equilibrium.

(a) Carefully determine the convergence of the series \sum\limits_{n=1}^{\infty} {(-1)^n\over 2^n}. The series is
absolutely convergent
conditionally convergent
divergent

(b) Carefully determine the convergence of the series \sum\limits_{n=1}^{\infty} {(-1)^n\left({n+1\over n}\right)}. The series is
absolutely convergent
conditionally convergent
divergent

static.solution:
(a) For \sum\limits_{n=1}^{\infty} {(-1)^n\over 2^n}, we have \lim\limits_{n\to\infty} {1\over 2^n} = 0. Thus, by the alternating series test, we know that this series converges (it is at least conditionally convergent). Because \sum\limits_{n=1}^{\infty} {1\over 2^n} also converges (by comparison to a p-series or by the integral test), our original series must be not only conditionally convergent but absolutely convergent.
(b) For \sum\limits_{n=1}^{\infty} {(-1)^n\left({n+1\over n}\right)}, we have \lim\limits_{n\to\infty} {n+1\over n} = 1. This means that the alternating series test doesn't tell us whether this series converges: if the limit had been zero, we would know that the series converged, but if it's non-zero the test doesn't help. However, note that \lim\limits_{n\to\infty}\left({n+1\over n}\right) = 1 \ne 0. Thus \lim\limits_{n\to\infty} (-1)^n\left({n+1\over n}\right) doesn't exist, and we know that the series must in fact diverge.

statement.p: For the following alternating series,
how many terms do you have to compute in order for your approximation (your partial sum) to be within 0.0000001 from the convergent value of that series?

static.solution:
\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty (-1)^{n-1} b_n satisfying the conditions of the alternating series test, i.e.
1. b_n \ge 0 for all n,
2. b_{n+1} \le b_n for all n,
3. \displaystyle \lim_{n+1} b_n = 0,
we have the error estimate |s_n - s| \le b_{n+1}.
The given series satisfies the above conditions. Therefore we have to find the first term which is less than or equal 0.0000001.
b_1 = 0.45 > 0.0000001,
b_2 = \frac{(0.45)^3}{3!} = 0.0151875 > 0.0000001,
b_3 = \frac{(0.45)^5}{5!} = 0.0001537734375 > 0.0000001,
b_4 = \frac{(0.45)^7}{7!} = 7.41407645089286e-07 > 0.0000001,
b_5 = \frac{(0.45)^9}{9!} = 2.08520900181362e-09 \lt 0.0000001.
Therefore we have to compute the sum of the first 4 terms.

statement.p: Use the figure below, which gives a graph of the function f(x), to give values for the indicated limits. If a limit does not exist, enter none.
(a) \lim\limits_{x \rightarrow -1} f(x) =
(b) \lim\limits_{x \rightarrow 0} f(x) =
(c) \lim\limits_{x \rightarrow 1} f(x) =
(d) \lim\limits_{x \rightarrow 4} f(x) =

static.solution:
(a) As x approaches -1 from either side, the values of f(x) get closer and closer to 6, so the limit appears to be about 6.
(b) As x approaches 0 from either side, the values of f(x) get closer and closer to 7. (Recall that to find a limit, we are interested in what happens to the function near x but not at x.) The limit appears to be about 7.
(c) As x approaches 1 from either side, the values of f(x) get closer and closer to 6 on one side of x = 1 and get closer and closer to -8 on the other side of x = 1. Thus the limit does not exist.
(d) As x approaches 4 from either side, the values of f(x) get closer and closer to -2. (Again, recall that we don't care what happens right at x = 4.) The limit appears to be about -2.

Find the Taylor polynomials of degree n approximating \cos\!\left(3x\right) for x near 0:

static.solution:
f(x) = \cos\!\left(3x\right) Then f(0) = \cos(0) = 1, and f'(x) = -3\sin\!\left(3x\right),\qquad \hbox{so}\quad f'(0) = 0, f''(x) = -9\cos\!\left(3x\right),\qquad \hbox{so}\quad f''(0) = -9, f'''(x) = 27\sin\!\left(3x\right),\qquad \hbox{so}\quad f'''(0) = 0, f^{4}(x) = 81\cos\!\left(3x\right),\qquad \hbox{so}\quad f^{4}(0) = 81, f^{5}(x) = -243\sin\!\left(3x\right),\qquad \hbox{so}\quad f^{5}(0) = 0, f^{6}(x) = (-729*cos(3*x)),\qquad \hbox{so}\quad f^{6}(0) = -729,
Thus, P_{2}(x) = 1 - {9\over2} x^2, P_{4}(x) = 1 - {9\over2} x^2 + {27\over4} x^4, and P_{6}(x) = 1 - {9\over2} x^2 + {27\over4} x^4 - {81\over80} x^6.

statement.p: Suppose g is a function which has continuous derivatives, and that g(6)=1, g'(6)=3, g''(6)=-1, g'''(6)=5.
(a) What is the Taylor polynomial of degree 2 for g near 6?
(b) What is the Taylor polynomial of degree 3 for g near 6?
(c) Use the two polynomials that you found in parts (a) and (b) to approximate g(6.1).
With P_2, g(6.1)\approx
With P_3, g(6.1)\approx

static.solution:
g(x) = g(6) + g'(6)(x-6) + \frac{g''(6)}{2!}(x-6)^2 +\frac{g'''(6)}{3!}(x-6)^3+\cdots Substituting gives g(x) = 1 + 3(x-6) + \frac{-1}{2!}(x-6)^2 +\frac{5}{3!}(x-6)^3+\cdots
(a) The degree 2 Taylor polynomial, P_2 (x), is obtained by truncating after the (x-6)^2 term: P_2(x) = 1+3\!\left(x-6\right)+\frac{1}{2!}\!\left(-1\right)\!\left(x-6\right)^{2}.
(b) The degree 3 Taylor polynomial, P_3 (x), is obtained by truncating after the (x-6)^3 term: P_3 (x) = 1+3\!\left(x-6\right)+\frac{1}{2!}\!\left(-1\right)\!\left(x-6\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{3!}\cdot 5\!\left(x-6\right)^{3}
(c) Substitute x=6.1 into the Taylor polynomial of degree 2: P_2(4.9) = 1+3\!\left(6.1-6\right)+\frac{1}{2!}\!\left(-1\right)\!\left(6.1-6\right)^{2} = 1.295. From the Taylor polynomial of degree 3, we obtain P_3(4.9) = 1+3\!\left(6.1-6\right)+\frac{1}{2!}\!\left(-1\right)\!\left(6.1-6\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{3!}\cdot 5\!\left(6.1-6\right)^{3} = 1.29583.

statement.p: Find the first four terms of the Taylor series for the function \displaystyle \frac{5}{x} about the point a = -1. (Your answers should include the variable x when appropriate.)
\displaystyle \frac{5}{x} = + + + + ...

static.solution:
\displaystyle \frac{5}{x} and its first three derivatives are
f(x) = \displaystyle \frac{5}{x}, f'(x) = -{5\over x^2}, f''(x) = {10\over x^3}, and f'''(x) = -{30\over x^4}. Thus, evaluating these at x = -1, we get the terms
term 0 = {-5}
term 1 = -{5}(x + 1)
term 2 = {-5}(x + 1)^2, and
term 3 = -{5}(x + 1)^3.
Thus the series is \displaystyle \frac{5}{x} = {-5} - {5}(x + 1) + {-5}(x + 1)^2 - {5}(x + 1)^3 + \cdots.

statement.p: Find the first four terms of the Taylor series for the function 5 \cos(x) about the point a = \pi/4. (Your answers should include the variable x when appropriate.)

static.solution:
5 \cos(x) and its first three derivatives are
f(x) = 5 \cos(x), f'(x) = -5 \sin(x), f''(x) = -5 \cos(x), and f'''(x) = 5 \sin(x). Thus, evaluating these at x = \pi/4, we get the terms
term 0 = {5\over\sqrt2}
term 1 = -{5\over\sqrt2}(x - {\pi\over 4})
term 2 = -{5\over2\sqrt2}(x - {\pi\over4})^2, and
term 3 = {{5\over6\sqrt2}}(x - {\pi\over4})^3.
Thus the series is 5 \cos(x) = {5\over\sqrt2} - {5\over\sqrt2}(x - {\pi\over 4}) - {5\over2\sqrt2}(x - {\pi\over4})^2 + {{5\over6\sqrt2}}(x - {\pi\over4})^3 + \cdots.

Represent the function \displaystyle \frac{3}{(1 - 3 x)} as a power series \displaystyle f(x) = \sum_{n=0}^\infty c_n x^n
Find the radius of convergence R = .

static.solution:
\displaystyle \frac{3}{1-3 x} = 3 \cdot \sum_{n=0}^\infty (3 x)^n. Then we can see that c_n = 3 \cdot 3^n, making c_0 = 3, c_1 = 3 \cdot 3 = 9, c_2 = 3 \cdot 3^2 = 27, etc.
Regarding the radius of convergence, we perform the standard ratio test: \lim_{n\to\infty} \left| \frac{3(3 x)^{n+1}}{3(3 x)^n} \right| = \lim_{n\to\infty} \left| 3 x \right| = \left| 3 x \right| And then \left| 3 x \right| \lt 1 \iff \left| x \right| \lt \frac 1 {3}, making R = \frac 1 {3}.

static.solution: f'(3) using the average rate of change formula on a small interval around 3. Let's try the interval from x = 3 to x = 3 + 0.0001. Then we have f'(3) \approx {f(3+0.0001) - f(3)\over 0.0001} = {6^{3.0001} - 6^{3}\over 0.0001} \approx 387, rounded to one decimal place. We can check that this is accurate to within 0.1 by testing a smaller interval, say from x = 3 to x = 3 + 0.00001. For this, we have f'(3) \approx {f(3+0.00001) - f(3)\over 0.00001} = {6^{3.00001} - 6^{3}\over 0.00001} \approx 387. This agrees with our previous result to one decimal place, so f'(3)\approx 387 is a good estimate.

statement.p: Carefully sketch the derivative function of the given function (you will want to estimate values on the derivative function at different x values as you do this). Use your derivative function graph to estimate the following values on the derivative function.

static.solution:

statement.p: At exactly two of the labeled points in the figure below, which shows a function f, the derivative f' is zero; the second derivative f'' is not zero at any of the labeled points. Select the correct signs for each of f, f' and f'' at each marked point.

static.solution:
f is positive, negative, or zero by whether the point is plotted above, below, or on the x-axis. The sign of f' is determined by the slope of the function at the point: if the function is increasing, then f'>0; if it is decreasing, f'\lt 0, and if it is neither increasing nor decreasing, then f'=0. Similarly, the sign of f'' is determined by the concavity of the function: if the function is concave up, then f''>0, if it is concave down, f''\lt 0. This gives the table
Point A B C D E
f negative zero negative negative negative
f' zero positive negative zero positive
f'' positive positive positive positive positive

statement.p: Use the figure below, which gives a graph of the function f(x), to give values for the indicated limits. If a limit does not exist, enter none.

(b) \lim\limits_{x \rightarrow 0} f(x) =
(c) \lim\limits_{x \rightarrow 2} f(x) =
(d) \lim\limits_{x \rightarrow 3} f(x) =

static.solution:
(a) As x approaches -2 from either side, the values of f(x) get closer and closer to -6, so the limit appears to be about -6.
(b) As x approaches 0 from either side, the values of f(x) get closer and closer to -10. (Recall that to find a limit, we are interested in what happens to the function near x but not at x.) The limit appears to be about -10.
(c) As x approaches 2 from either side, the values of f(x) get closer and closer to -6 on one side of x = 2 and get closer and closer to 0 on the other side of x = 2. Thus the limit does not exist.
(d) As x approaches 3 from either side, the values of f(x) get closer and closer to 4. (Again, recall that we don't care what happens right at x = 3.) The limit appears to be about 4.

statement.p: Suppose that f(x) is a function with f(125) = 70 and f'(125) = 6. Estimate f(123).

static.solution: f(125) = 70 and f'(125) = 6 tell us that at x = 125, the value of the function is 70 and the function is increasing at a rate of 6 units for a unit increase in x. Since we increase x by -2 units in going from 125 to 123, the value of the function goes up by approximately -2 \cdot 6 = -12 units, so f(123) \approx 70 - 2 \cdot 6 = 70 - 12 = 58.

Since f(x) is linear on the interval 0 \lt x \lt 2, we compute the slope of the line to see that f'(x) = 1.5 on this interval. Find the derivative of the function f(t), below.
Find the derivative of the function g(t), below. It may be to your advantage to simplify before differentiating.
Find the derivative of the function h(w), below. It may be to your advantage to simplify before differentiating.
For x>0, find and simplify the derivative of f(x) = \arctan x + \arctan(1/x).
(What does your result tell you about f)?

static.solution:
f'(x) = \frac{1}{1+x^2}+\frac{1}{1+\frac{1}{x^2}}\cdot (-\frac{1}{x^2}), or, simplifying the second term, f'(x) = \frac{1}{1+x^2}+\left(-\frac{1}{x^2+1}\right) = \frac{1}{1+x^2}-\frac{1}{1+x^2} = 0.
Thus f is a constant function! We can check a few values to confirm this: f(1) = \arctan(1) + \arctan(1) \approx 0.785392 + 0.7853982 = 1.5707963,
f(2) = \arctan(2) + \arctan(\frac12) \approx 1.1071487 + 0.4636476 = 1.5707963, and
f(3) = \arctan(3) + \arctan(\frac13) \approx 1.2490458 + 0.3217506 = 1.5707963.

statement.p: Let (x_0, y_0) = (2, 5) and (x_1, y_1) = (2.1, 5.4). Use the following graph of the function f to find the indicated derivatives.
If h(x)=(f(x))^{5}, then
If g(x)=f^{-1}(x), then

static.solution:
(2,5) is on the curve, we know f(2)=5. The point (2.1,5.4) is on the tangent line, so \hbox{Slope of tangent} = \frac{5.4-5}{2.1-2} = \frac{0.4}{0.1} = 4. Thus, f'(2)=4.
By the chain rule h'(2) = 5(f(2))^{4}\cdot f'(2) =5\cdot 5^{4}\cdot 4 = 12500.
Because g(x) is the inverse function of f, we know that g(5) = 2. Then note that f(g(x)) = f(f^{-1}(x)) = x, so f(g(x)) = x. Differentiating both sides of the equation, f'(g(x))\cdot g'(x) = 1, so g'(x) = \frac{1}{f'(g(x))}. Thus g'(5) = \frac{1}{f'(g(5))} = \frac{1}{f'(2)} = \frac1{4}.

statement.p: Let f(x) = \displaystyle 7\cos\!\left(x\right)\sin^{-1}\!\left(x\right). Find f'(x).
Find dy/dx in terms of x and y if x^{5} y - x - 3 y - 14 =0.

solution.p: We differentiate implicitly with respect to x. This gives 5 x^{4} y - x^{5} \, \frac{dy}{dx} - 1 - 3 \, \frac{dy}{dx} = 0, or (x^{5}-3) \, \frac{dy}{dx} = 1-5x^{4}y, and so \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{1 - 5 x^{4} y}{x^{5} - 3}.

We differentiate implicitly both sides of the equation with respect to x. \ln y + \frac xy \, \frac{dy}{dx} + 7 y^{6}\frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{8}{x}, so \left( \frac{x}{y} + 7 y^{6} \right) \, \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{8}{x} - \ln y, and thus \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{\frac{8}{x} - \ln y}{\frac{x}{y} + 7 y^{6}} = \frac{y\!\left(8-x\ln\!\left(y\right)\right)}{x\!\left(x+7y^{7}\right)}.

statement.p: Find dy/dx in terms of x and y if \arcsin(x^{2} y) = x y^{2}.

static.solution: x. \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - x^{4} y^2}} (2 x y + x^{2} \frac{dy}{dx}) = y^{2} + 2 x y \frac{dy}{dx}, so, clearing the denominator, 2 x y + x^{2} \frac{dy}{dx} = \sqrt{1 - x^{4} y^2} (y^{2} + 2 x y \frac{dy}{dx}). Thus ( x^{2} - (2 x y) \sqrt{1 - x^{4} y^2} ) \frac{dy}{dx} = y^{2} \sqrt{1 - x^{4} y^2} - 2 x y, and finally \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{y^{2} \sqrt{1 - x^{4} y^2} - 2 x y}{x^{2} - (2 x y) \sqrt{1 - x^{4} y^2}}.

statement.p: Find the slope of the tangent to the curve x^{2}+2xy+y^{2} = 4 at (1,1).
The slope is .

p.em: (Enter undef if the slope is not defined at this point.)

solution.p: Differentiating with respect to x gives 2 x + 2 y + 2 x y' + 2y y'=0 so that y' = -\frac{2 x + 2 y}{2 x + 2 y}.
At the point (1,1) the slope is - \frac{2\cdot 1+2\cdot 1}{2\cdot 1+2\cdot 1} = -1.

statement.p: Use implicit differentiation to find an equation of the tangent line to the curve 4xy^{3}+xy = 35 at the point \left(7,1\right).
The equation defines the tangent line to the curve at the point \left(7,1\right).

solution.p: Differentiating implicitly with respect to x gives 4 y^3 + 12 x y^2 \, \frac{dy}{dx} + y + x \, \frac{dy}{dx} = 0. If x = 7 and y = 1, then this equation becomes 5 + 91 \, \frac{dy}{dx} = 0, \qquad \text{and so} \qquad \frac{dy}{dx} = -{\frac{5}{91}}. If (x, y) is any point on the tangent line besides \left(7,1\right) then -{\frac{5}{91}} = \frac{y-1}{x-7}, \qquad \text{or} \qquad 5\!\left(x-7\right) = -91\!\left(y-1\right). Therefore, 5x+91y = 126 is an equation of the line tangent to the curve at the point \left(7,1\right).

statement.p: For the figures below, determine the nature of \displaystyle \lim_{x\to a}\,\frac{f(x)}{g(x)}, if f(x) is shown as the blue curve and g(x) as the black curve.

For the left graph, since f'(a) \lt 0 and g'(a) \lt 0, the limit is positive..
For the right graph, since f'(a) = 0 and g'(a) \ne 0, the limit is zero..

To apply l'Hopital's rule, we first find f'(x)=1/x and g'(x)=2x, then \lim_{x \rightarrow 4} \frac{\ln(x/4)}{x^2-16} = \lim_{x \rightarrow 4} \frac{1/x}{2x}=\lim_{x \rightarrow 4} \frac{1}{2x^2}=\frac{1}{32}.

solution.p: SOLUTION
From the graph, we see that f(x) appears to have one critical point, at x=0, and two inflection points, one between 0 and 1 and the other between 0 and -1.
To find the critical points, we set f'(x) = 0. Since f'(x) = {2(8)x\over 8 x^2 + 1} = 0, there is one solution, x = 0. The only critical point is at x=0.

To find the inflection points, we find f''(x) and determine where it is zero. f''(x) = {16 (8 x^2 + 1) - 256 x^2\over(8 x^2+1)^2} = {16( 1 - 8 x^2 )\over(8 x^2+1)^2}. For this to be zero, we must have -1 + 8 x^2 = 0, or x = \pm 1/\sqrt{8}. There are exactly two inflection points, at x = -1/\sqrt{8} \approx -0.354 and x = 1/\sqrt{8} \approx 0.354.

statement.p: Find the inflection points of f(x)=6 x^4 + 34 x^3 - 18 x^2 + 12. (Give your answers as a comma separated list, e.g., 3,-2.)
inflection points =

solution.p: SOLUTION

We find inflection points by determining where f''(x) changes sign. f'(x) = 6\cdot 4x^{3}+34\cdot 3x^{2}-18\cdot 2x, so f''(x) = 6\cdot 4\cdot 3x^{2}+34\cdot 3\cdot 2x-36 = 12(6 x - 1)(x + 3). So we see that f''(x) changes sign at x = 1/6 and x = -3.
